all_paragraphs: Following our first math class in high school, our new teacher gave us a page with 7 problems involving polynomials. Although I don’t remember any of the specific problems, I remember the level of panic in class the following days. The whole class was shocked because previously we only encountered at most quadratic equations … Now he wants us to solve problems involving these mythical creatures that can go up to as much “n” as they want and who knows if they even have analytic solutions ? (Galois knows. They mostly don’t)
The next thing he taught us about was generating functions and recursions. He showed us the general formula for Fibonacci numbers, and how Euler derived his famous summation of the Basel problem.

Then, I did my first degree in math. To my absolute surprise, I never really encountered any of these stuff again. Back in high school, I was sure this was what Mathematics is all about, but now as a more mature and educated scholar, I knew these were ancient math and children games.
Imagine my second surprise when deep into my Masters degree, dealing with problems related to Game theory, these exact subjects of polynomials and recurrences came back up in the most natural way ..!

Cutting away from my heartwarming personal story, I wish in this post to give a few nuggets of the place of experiments in math, and how you can ‘Do math like a data scientist’. Of course it’s considered total heresy to think of math as experimentation — That’s the induction fallacy, right ? But actually the art of guessing has a lot of place in Mathematics, and if you can later wrap your guess with a complete argument then you could end up rigorously valid.

Let’s start with some pre-requisite software. There is a lot of symbolic mathematics software out there — coq and sage and maple and what have you. In this world you can not be picky in the way you can be picky in the software development startup world — For any specific use that you wish to make of the software, if it’s not totally standard, good chances are there is only one implementation out there — so whether it’s in Maple, Matlab or in a proprietary framework someone developed in assembly for microwave chips — you are going to have to learn to use it. Anyway for the purposes of following this post I recommend you have python, Mathematica and Matlab installed. In case you don’t, you can still follow up on the simple code explanation and results.

In the RISC institute down in Linz, Austria they developed the amazing RISCErgosum package for Mathematica. This package can basically prove any identity you can think of. Let’s see it in action proving an Euler paper from 250 years ago — as described in this nice article summary.

In the article, Euler was deriving a general formula for the so called central trinomial coefficients, by methods of finding a recurrence they satisfy. He dedicates a full chapter to a failed attempt he had where a simple recurrence based on Fibonacci series seemed to hold, but by computing enough terms of the series Euler eventually managed to see this recurrence does not generally hold and found the correct expression. Let’s see another example of an experimental approach applied in solving a question in Renewal processes. Imagine the following petting zoo managed by a bored teenager.

Kids get turns in going in the petting zoo. Every time a group of kids is let in, with i.i.d intervals T1,T2,T3,… which are distributed Geo(p), since the teenager sometimes does his job, but sometimes also slacks off for longer and longer times. But since he knows he’s going to slack off, he enters a number of kids Nk so that Nk-s are independent but the conditional distribution of Nk given Tk+1 = n is Uni{1,…,n+2}. So even though he’s slacking off, more kids will go in, so it should be ok. The question is, what is the average time in the long run that kids will spend in the petting zoo ?

Well, even without doing the exact calculation you can be quite sure that the formula we’re looking for is a rational function. That’s because it’s going to be some ratio between expectations that involve uniform and geometric distributions, which probably will be low order polynomials in p. We can then use any tool to fit a rational function to our acquired simulation data, I used cftool of Matlab -

You can see the fit is actually great. In real life, I didn’t use cftool, but rather since I kept having arithmetic mistakes in the analytic calculation, I used the simulation to determine the exact expression by doing some value guessing. If I had a harder time in the first few guesses though, I would resort to some kind of rational functions fitting program.
Now, maybe the most important question about conducting experiments is when to stop. How many tries is enough ?

For some algebraic entities that have a notion of degree or dimension we know the answer. A polynomial of degree n is determined by n+1 points. Thus, it’s enough to sample n+1 points of the polynomial to uniquely determine its complete form. A similar thing applies to a recurrence of order n — if we know the recurrence holds for our series, and we have n points where our series expression identifies with a solution of the recurrence, then given that nothing too bad is going on with the recurrence expression, we can roll on inductively and get a true identity.

I will cite one result from there, which is cool:

When you want to get an equidistributed deck of cards, the ‘safest’ way to do so is to pick up a random card to go first, then a random card of the remaining ones to be second, and so on. But this would require you to make a choice out of 52 cards in the first step, 51 in the second … You will end up needing to choose one deck of cards out of possible 52!.

But, what happens in real life too, is you take a deck of cards that is not random, and you trust that after a few shuffles it will be as good as random. It’s obvious that if you only move one or two cards around in the deck it wouldn’t make a difference. And also it’s obvious that if you go on doing this forever and a day, the deck of cards will be randomized. When is the right time to stop ? Read the overview and you will see that about NlogN ~ 400 single card replacements should do the trick. Here they came up with the number 277. Of course, if you do a rifle shuffle it can take much less as in every “shuffle” you get much more single steps happen.
If this post got you even a little bit interested in computer algebra, experimental math or stochastic simulation, I highly recommend these as further reading:
A=B, a great book on the art and science of proving identities using recurrence relations
An experimental math manifesto by Doron Zeilberger, an author of the A=B book
A great and practical book about stochastic simulation done right by Asmussen
